item.title: Metals Higher as Dollar Eases
item.description: Base metals and gold prices rose on a falling dollar and uncertain macroeconomic outlook, as investors looked to this week’s key inflation data points, with US consumer and producer price indexes due.

item.title: Oil Prices Ease But Cuts Keeps Brent Above $90 a Barrel
item.description: Oil prices edged at the start of the week, but support from shrinking supply from Saudi Arabia and Russia has helped to contain losses.

item.title: Eurozone Bond Yields Rise Amid Headwinds from Japan
item.description: Eurozone government bond yields rose with the knock-on effect from Japan which is clearly visible this morning, Commerzbank Research said, referring to a hint at the end of negative interest rates policy in the country.

item.title: Private Jets and Pop-Up Workspaces: Boeing Eases Return to Office for Top Brass
item.description: Company flight patterns suggest CEO Calhoun travels infrequently to headquarters from two distant homes, while CFO West occupies a new office five minutes from his Connecticut doorstep.

item.title: Economic Divergence Between US, Eurozone Seen Key for EUR/USD
item.description: The current focus for EUR/USD has returned to the relative difference between the U.S and European economies, thus ruling out a near- and medium-term scenario of a decline in the dollar index, XS.com said.

item.title: Olam Group Denies Fraud Allegations; Shares Tumble
item.description: Olam Group has denied two news reports that alleged that the commodity trader’s Nigerian units and subsidiaries were involved in a multibillion-dollar fraud.

item.title: Covestro In Takeover Talks With ADNOC
item.description: Covestro confirmed it has entered talks over a potential €12 billion takeover by Abu Dhabi National Oil Co.

item.title: HSBC Seen As Buying Opportunity
item.description: Sentiment around HSBC seems intertwined with recent share price moves, despite convictions of above consensus earnings and returns, Jefferies said following investor meetings with the bank’s Asia CFO.

item.title: Brookfield, SocGen to Launch Private-Debt Fund
item.description: Brookfield and Societe Generale joined forces to set up a private-debt fund worth €10 billion over the next four years, a move the companies said will significantly increase their financing footprint while addressing growing demand for private debt.

item.title: Chinese Banks' Loan Issuance Beat Expectations
item.description: Chinese banks issued a higher-than-expected amount of new loans in August, as Beijing tapped the nation’s financial institutions to step up support for the cooling economy.

item.title: How Cuba Fits Into China's Global Eavesdropping Strategy
item.description: China is using bases in Cuba to monitor communications and gather intelligence throughout the southeastern U.S., a practice known as signals intelligence. Here’s the technology involved, and what the U.S. is doing to defend itself.

item.title: Chevron Appeals to Australian Workplace Arbiter to Resolve Labor Impasse
item.description: Chevron has asked Australia’s workplace arbiter to intervene to resolve a labor dispute at two giant natural-gas operations after negotiations with union representatives failed and workers began partial strikes at the sites.

item.title: Xi's consolidation of power over China's economy is delaying the country's response to its worst slowdown in years as senior officials have been inhibited from rolling out major stimulus or making significant policy changes.
item.description: Xi’s consolidation of power over China’s economy is delaying the country’s response to its worst slowdown in years as senior officials have been inhibited from rolling out major stimulus or making significant policy changes.

item.title: Hostess Brands, owner of Twinkies, is closing in on a sale to J.M. Smucker, a move that would combine two big names in snacks.
item.description: Hostess Brands, owner of Twinkies, is closing in on a sale to J.M. Smucker, a move that would combine two big names in snacks.

item.title: The U.S. and Saudi Arabia are in talks to secure metals in Africa needed for both countries' energy transitions, people with knowledge of the talks said.
item.description: The U.S. and Saudi Arabia are in talks to secure metals in Africa needed for both countries’ energy transitions, people with knowledge of the talks said.

item.title: Wall Street expects corporate earnings to rebound after three quarters of year-over-year declines, a development that could put the stock market's faltering rally on a firmer footing.
item.description: Wall Street expects corporate earnings to rebound after three quarters of year-over-year declines, a development that could put the stock market’s faltering rally on a firmer footing.

item.title: Instacart is targeting a valuation of roughly $8.6 billion to $9.3 billion in its imminent IPO, a fraction of what the grocery-delivery company was previously worth.
item.description: Instacart is targeting a valuation of roughly $8.6 billion to $9.3 billion in its imminent IPO, a fraction of what the grocery-delivery company was previously worth.

item.title: The U.S. labor market is cooling, with companies hiring more slowly and reducing job postings as higher interest rates weigh on economic demand.
item.description: The U.S. labor market is cooling, with companies hiring more slowly and reducing job postings as higher interest rates weigh on economic demand.

item.title: California would force large corporations that do business in the state to disclose all greenhouse-gas emissions associated with their operations, under a bill being considered by the legislature.
item.description: California would force large corporations that do business in the state to disclose all greenhouse-gas emissions associated with their operations, under a bill being considered by the legislature.

item.title: A rise in Covid cases and the approach of fall, when other respiratory illnesses start to spread, has revived discussion of how best to protect students and workers.
item.description: A rise in Covid cases and the approach of fall, when other respiratory illnesses start to spread, has revived discussion of how best to protect students and workers.
